name: NPR
text:
NEW: White House adviser Stephen Miller has tested positive for the coronavirus — the latest in a string of nearly 2 dozen positive cases in the last week among close contacts to the White House.
https://t.co/oafZ56zhcQ

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is "mocking us, the working poor," says Norma, one of the roughly 2 million domestic workers in the U.S.

She and her mother were infected with the coronavirus earlier this year. 

Norma survived. Her mom did not. https://t.co/WE2AMEja1G

name: NPR
text:
Mark and Patricia McCloskey, the white St. Louis couple charged in July with waving firearms at Black Lives Matter protesters, have been indicted by a grand jury, the AP reports.
https://t.co/OFnNL7QY7l

name: NPR
text:
President Trump, who has continually dismissed the danger of the coronavirus, has received VIP treatment since he tested positive.

That includes an antibody cocktail from Regeneron — which fewer than 10 people have received outside of clinical trials.
https://t.co/qqWEpiM9a7

name: NPR
text:
Little Big Town, one of the biggest bands in country music, put on a Tiny Desk quarantine show. And they brought the hits.
https://t.co/WqlC6mghE6

name: NPR
text:
For many married women, one of South Korea's biggest holidays — Chuseok — traditionally involves visiting their in-laws and spending the time cooking and cleaning.

But because of the pandemic, many stayed home this year.
https://t.co/ToO5ifOyKd

name: NPR
text: Whale researchers normally work in teams, but that’s next to impossible these days. To keep tabs on the elusive and often endangered creatures, researchers have had to get creative. For some, it’s meant adding their spouses and even their pets to the team. https://t.co/IcYWBxj9C9

name: NPR
text:
There was an 81% increase in COVID-19 tests in D.C. Monday compared to a week ago.

"People work in the White House, and those people also shop at my grocery store and are out about town. It feels frankly really scary," said one resident.
https://t.co/oyy4UyszxB

name: NPR
text:
Most colleges holding in-person classes aren’t regularly testing students for the coronavirus, data obtained by NPR shows.

That could lead to even more cases later this fall, when the semester ends and students head home.
https://t.co/uyL39tKEBz

name: NPR
text:
For months, many experts who study the airborne transmission of viruses have been warning that the coronavirus can spread through the air.

Now, the CDC is acknowledging the same thing.
https://t.co/u6b8YyYjls

name: NPR
text:
These Republican senators are currently in quarantine:

• Ron Johnson*
• Ted Cruz
• James Lankford
• Mike Lee*
• Ben Sasse
• Thom Tillis*

*Tested positive for the coronavirus
https://t.co/hD9JwIXUOa

name: NPR
text:
The requirements for emergency authorization of a COVID-19 vaccine, laid out in new FDA guidance, underscore why it's unlikely a vaccine could clear the agency before Election Day.
https://t.co/yC660TyEo1

name: NPR
text:
Kamala Harris has called her time at Howard University "one of the most important aspects of my life."

Much of that time was spent studying economics — and becoming president of the Abram Harris Economics Society. (@planetmoney)
https://t.co/7csqIXxhw0

name: NPR
text:
Making a career switch can be daunting — but it *is* doable.

Don’t think of it as starting from square one. You have a wealth of transferable skills that you’ll bring with you.

More from @nprlifekit 👇
https://t.co/RfjXO7ncAD

name: NPR
text:
The Trump and Biden campaigns are both targeting Catholic voters in the swing state of Pennsylvania.

The GOP hopes opposition to abortion will fuel support for Trump. But Biden is a native of the state — and a lifelong Catholic who regularly attends mass.
https://t.co/3qZuEtUi3d

name: NPR
text:
The government scientist Rick Bright has resigned from the NIH, alleging top federal health officials blocked his efforts to roll out a plan aimed at better identifying and testing people with the coronavirus.
https://t.co/KUBEkp8ZxL

name: NPR
text: "The Rarities" is an indispensable addition to Mariah Carey's catalog as well as an illuminating, if incomplete, survey of pop and R&B as they've evolved over the past 30 years, Andrew Chan writes for @NPRMusic. https://t.co/SizlqNxoGD

name: NPR
text: Nine ZIP codes in New York City have seen persistently high rates of coronavirus infections. Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to close nonessential businesses and schools there Wednesday, pending state approval. https://t.co/SbmkavnaBq

name: NPR
text:
White House deputy press secretary Brian Morgenstern told NPR on Tuesday that masks are not currently mandated inside the White House.

And officials still won't say the total number of coronavirus cases among White House personnel.
https://t.co/d3qiAmTnUP

name: NPR
text:
The 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to two researchers who developed new techniques of genome editing — Emmanuelle Charpentier of France, and Jennifer Doudna of the U.S.
https://t.co/IaKpUwO2zm

name: NPR
text:
Once President Trump was diagnosed, public health guidelines dictated that he be isolated to help prevent the spread.

Instead, he took a joy ride between medical treatments at Walter Reed, exposing Secret Service agents to the coronavirus in the process.
https://t.co/XqNnv1HeKg

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden says “we shouldn’t have a debate” next week if President Trump is still infected with the coronavirus.

His comments came after Trump, who continues treatment for COVID-19, tweeted he was looking forward to next week's debate. https://t.co/b84MBDgtQ2

name: NPR
text:
Stocks opened higher, reversing yesterday's losses, amid word that Trump administration officials are considering stand-alone bills to aid airlines and small businesses.

Trump had called off negotiations on a stimulus bill in a tweet yesterday.
https://t.co/4DoFQJIMyd

name: NPR
text:
Speaking in Gettysburg, Joe Biden tried to frame his call for national unity within the arc of American history.

"Today, once again, we are a house divided," he said, echoing the words of President Lincoln. "But that, my friends, can no longer be."
https://t.co/asOsUYv6td

name: NPR
text:
President Trump and close to a dozen key contacts in his circle — including senior White House and campaign staff, and Republican senators — have tested positive for the coronavirus in recent days.

Here's who has tested positive so far ⤵️
https://t.co/XI7XxImPFO

name: NPR
text:
Hurricane Delta is emerging back into the Gulf of Mexico after making landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula as a Category 2 storm, the National Hurricane Center said.

It has weakened, but it's expected to regain power before approaching the U.S. Coast Friday.
https://t.co/Ax7ReJBSe6

name: NPR
text:
A top aide to Speaker Nancy Pelosi tweeted that she spoke to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on the phone today and he inquired about a standalone measure to help airlines.

A previous attempt to do this failed — amid Republican opposition.
https://t.co/5kGwgG64Ff

name: NPR
text:
More than 7.5 million cases of the coronavirus have been identified in the U.S., and more than 210,000 people have died.

The latest data:
https://t.co/E0M3cShZdK

name: NPR
text:
Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin has been released from jail after posting a $1 million bond. He faces charges of murder and manslaughter in the death of George Floyd in May.
https://t.co/VOBSaKEhab

name: NPR
text:
A plexiglass barrier may not be enough protection against coronavirus spreading through the air, scientists say.

Now, some are recommending that debate organizers adopt this simple, air-cleaning contraption on stage.
https://t.co/kMDeEyZtqJ

name: NPR
text:
The list of people in President Trump's circle who are testing positive for the coronavirus grows daily — and it's not clear to observers that those exposed will actually quarantine.
https://t.co/DduIgZHCrz

name: NPR
text:
Arsenal midfielder Mesut Özil has offered to pay the full salary of the team's mascot Gunnersaurus, who is played by Jerry Quy.

"I'm offering to reimburse Arsenal with the full salary of our big green guy as long as I will be an Arsenal player," he wrote. https://t.co/LxWuSrXvQh

name: NPR
text:
A Greek court has ruled that Golden Dawn, a neo-Nazi party, is a criminal organization — convicting 68 party members of crimes including murder and attempted murder.

Outside the courtroom, huge crowds amassed, waving banners that read "Nazis in Prison."
https://t.co/xStLqMvH5X

name: NPR
text:
Johnny Nash — who sang the No. 1 hit "I Can See Clearly Now" in 1972 — has died at the age of 80.

In addition to his own singing, Nash also signed Bob Marley, Bunny Wailer and Peter Tosh to an exclusive deal early in their careers.
https://t.co/qnmrtVkqbv

name: NPR
text:
In tonight's debate, Mike Pence, who led the White House coronavirus task force, will have to defend the Trump administration's handling of the pandemic — and their failure to prevent the virus from spreading within the White House itself.
https://t.co/nG3disdMaM

name: NPR
text:
Computer antivirus pioneer John McAfee has been arrested in Spain on tax evasion charges and now faces extradition to the U.S.

Prosecutors say he failed to file tax returns from 2014 to 2018 — and concealed millions of dollars through various means.
https://t.co/Sj9IlQ8D6H

name: NPR
text: The White House has outlined steps it's taking to protect staff, but Kate Andersen Brower, author of The Residence: Inside the Private World of the White House, says there is ample cause for concern. https://t.co/5sEopUexe4

name: NPR
text:
RT @hansilowang: BREAKING: An appeals court has rejected another Trump administration attempt to end #2020Census counting before Oct. 31. From a 3-judge panel of the 9th Circuit:
https://t.co/YSpAQnsCQo https://t.co/krLzxT8Jb1

name: NPR
text:
"Seven months later, he still won't wear a mask consistently and encourage others to do the same," Michelle Obama said of President Trump. "Instead, he continues to gaslight the American people by acting like this pandemic is not a real threat."
https://t.co/3Qqg0oxpsD

name: NPR
text:
A new poll shows 1 in 4 rural American households have been unable to get medical care for serious problems during the pandemic.

Among those households, more than half reported a family member experiencing negative health consequences as a result.
https://t.co/Byy8P7ig00

name: NPR
text: The drug, Remdesivir, emerged in part because researchers had previously tested it in China through a project whose grant was abruptly ended by the National Institutes of Health. https://t.co/PDNmpAkjNc

name: NPR
text:
A federal appeals court has rejected another request by the Trump administration to end census counting before Oct. 31. The legal fight is likely to go to the Supreme Court.
https://t.co/zWENsyDIMD

name: NPR
text:
The 2020 election is going to be different than any election in U.S. history.

In a special report, NPR reporters Scott Detrow and Juana Summers explore how voters can navigate unprecedented challenges to casting a ballot this year.
https://t.co/FLkcNLZUG0

name: NPR
text:
Researchers say they've contacted the presidential debate commission — and both presidential campaigns — to recommend that they adopt a simple contraption that could be used as a localized air cleaner on stage.
https://t.co/iD6L4LM5jT

name: NPR
text:
Some Massachusetts voters say they were outraged to see Trump maskless in the White House while contagious.

"He's throwing gas kerosene on the fire," one man said.

"It's such a slap in the face to the 200,000 Americans who have died," his husband added.
https://t.co/aA4ZjpSaVc
